metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which sequence lists Earth’s layers in order from the outermost to the innermost?

answers.content: Crust → Mantle → Outer core → Inner core
answers.explanation: The crust forms Earth’s surface, followed by the mantle, then the liquid outer core and finally the solid inner core.

answers.content: Mantle → Crust → Inner core → Outer core
Crust → Outer core → Mantle → Inner core
Inner core → Outer core → Mantle → Crust

questions.question: Which layer is made of solid rock and includes continents and the ocean floor?

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is the rigid, rocky outer layer on which we live.

answers.content: Mantle
Outer core
Inner core

questions.question: Despite temperatures similar to the surface of the Sun, Earth’s inner core remains solid because

answers.content: immense pressure prevents the iron–nickel alloy from melting.
answers.explanation: The pressure at Earth’s centre is so great that it keeps the inner core solid.

answers.content: it contains mainly stone, not metal.
there is no heat source in the inner core.
gravity pulls all particles tightly together at the crust.

questions.question: Iron and nickel are the primary elements found in which TWO layers of Earth?

answers.content: Outer core and inner core
answers.explanation: Both parts of the core are composed mainly of molten or solid iron and nickel.

answers.content: Crust and mantle
Mantle and outer core
Crust and inner core

questions.question: Which statement about Earth’s mantle is TRUE?

answers.content: It is a semi-solid layer that moves slowly, driving surface changes such as volcanic eruptions.
answers.explanation: Convection currents in the mantle cause tectonic activity at the crust.

answers.content: It is completely liquid and colder than the crust.
It is the thinnest of all Earth’s layers.
It is composed mostly of iron and nickel.

questions.question: Give TWO differences between Earth’s outer core and inner core.

answers.content: The outer core is liquid while the inner core is solid; the inner core is under greater pressure.
answers.explanation: Accept any two correct contrasts such as state (liquid vs solid), thickness, or reason for solidity (pressure).

questions.question: Using appropriate Tier 2 and Tier 3 vocabulary, explain why volcanic eruptions often occur at the boundaries of Earth’s tectonic plates in the crust.

answers.content: At plate boundaries, convection currents in the mantle cause lithospheric plates to diverge, converge or slide past each other. This movement allows magma to ascend through fractures in the crust, producing volcanic eruptions.
answers.explanation: Responses should reference plate movement, magma, mantle convection and the crust.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-sectional diagram of Earth showing the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. Use colour and annotate thickness or temperature where possible.

answers.content: Teacher-scored drawing response
answers.explanation: Award full marks if all four layers are correctly ordered, clearly labelled and colour-differentiated.

questions.question: What is the immediate cause of most earthquakes?

answers.content: Sudden movement along a fault where tectonic plates are stuck
answers.explanation: Stress builds at plate boundaries until it is suddenly released, causing the ground to shake.

answers.content: Gradual sinking of Earth’s mantle
Heating of the inner core
High winds eroding the surface

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model, which part of the chocolate bar represents Earth’s crust?

answers.content: The solid chocolate coating
answers.explanation: The hard outer layer mimics the rigid lithosphere.

answers.content: The caramel layer
The nougat centre
The wrapper

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses the causal connective ‘so’ to explain an effect of the Noto Peninsula earthquake?

answers.content: The earthquake struck so the coastline rose by several metres.
answers.explanation: ‘So’ links the cause (earthquake) with the effect (uplift).

answers.content: The coastline rose, so the earthquake struck.
answers.explanation: This reverses cause and effect.

answers.content: The earthquake so struck the coastline rose.
So the coastline rose, the earthquake struck.

questions.question: Why does Australia experience fewer large earthquakes than countries such as Japan?

answers.content: It sits near the centre of a tectonic plate, far from most plate boundaries.
answers.explanation: Plate boundaries are where most seismic activity occurs.

answers.content: It is located on the equator where forces are weaker.
Its bedrock absorbs seismic energy completely.
It has no active faults anywhere on the continent.

questions.question: Purple flashes on the earthquake animation most likely indicated:

answers.content: Epicentres located beneath the ocean that generated tsunamis
answers.explanation: Ocean-based quakes can displace water and create tsunami waves.

answers.content: Volcanic eruptions happening at the same time
Lightning storms recorded by satellites
Areas of very deep mantle convection

questions.question: Which landscape change was reported after the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake?

answers.content: Sections of coastline were uplifted above sea level
answers.explanation: Observers saw land rise, exposing new shorelines.

answers.content: Snow avalanches buried several valleys
Volcanic lava flows covered farmland
A massive sinkhole swallowed an entire village

questions.question: Define the term ‘landscape’ as used in the lesson.

answers.content: Any natural or built feature found in a particular area
answers.explanation: Students should mention both natural and human-made elements.

questions.question: Explain how a tsunami can be generated by an under-sea earthquake.

answers.content: The quake suddenly moves the seafloor, displacing a large volume of water that travels outward as powerful waves.

questions.question: Complete the sentence: The tectonic plates met so Earth’s crust __________.

answers.content: buckled and cracked / folded / was pushed upward
answers.explanation: Any appropriate description of deformation of the crust earns the mark.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram showing two tectonic plates colliding at a convergent boundary. Include arrows to show direction of movement and at least one labelled change to the landscape (e.g., mountain uplift or trench formation).

answers.content: Teacher-marked drawing

questions.question: What name is given to molten rock after it reaches Earth’s surface during a volcanic eruption?

answers.content: Magma
answers.explanation: Magma is molten rock while it is still beneath Earth’s surface.

answers.content: Lava
answers.explanation: Once magma reaches the surface it is called lava.

answers.content: Ash
answers.explanation: Ash is the tiny rock fragments and gas that explode from a volcano.

questions.question: Most volcanoes occur where:

answers.content: Tectonic plates move apart or collide.
answers.explanation: Plate boundaries create weaknesses that allow magma to rise.

answers.content: Earth’s magnetic field is weakest.
answers.explanation: The magnetic field is not related to volcanism.

answers.content: Large rivers empty into the sea.
answers.explanation: River mouths are not linked to volcanic activity.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a constructive effect of a volcanic eruption?

answers.content: Ash destroying crops
answers.explanation: This is a destructive effect.

answers.content: Creation of new fertile soil
answers.explanation: Mineral-rich ash weathers into very fertile soil over time.

answers.content: Lava burying houses
answers.explanation: This damages the built environment.

questions.question: During the model activity, vinegar represents _______ and baking soda represents _______.

answers.content: lava; magma
answers.explanation: The fizzy mixture is the eruption, not the magma/lava difference.

answers.content: gas pressure; magma
answers.explanation: Acid (vinegar) reacting with baking soda produces gas pressure that forces the mixture (magma) up and out—mimicking an eruption.

answers.content: ash; lava
answers.explanation: Neither ingredient models ash in the activity.

questions.question: Write ONE compound or complex sentence explaining a knock-on effect that can occur AFTER new land is created by a volcanic eruption.

answers.content: Because the eruption built a new island, more plant species can colonise the area and provide habitats for birds.
answers.explanation: A correct response links the immediate change (new land) with a causal effect (e.g., habitat formation, increased space, tourism, etc.) using a connector like ‘because’, ‘therefore’, or ‘as a result’.

questions.question: Which pair correctly matches a discovery at Pompeii with what it taught archaeologists?

answers.content: Public baths – showed the Romans traded with China.
answers.explanation: The baths provided clues about hygiene, not international trade.

answers.content: Loaves of bread – revealed what Romans ate.
answers.explanation: Carbonised bread inside ovens gave evidence of diet.

answers.content: Gladiator school – proved Romans invented concrete.
answers.explanation: Concrete predates gladiator schools and the finds showed leisure activities.

questions.question: Why does gas build-up beneath a volcano often lead to an explosive eruption?

answers.content: Gas decreases the temperature of magma.
answers.explanation: Gas affects pressure, not temperature.

answers.content: Trapped gas increases pressure until the crust cracks open.
answers.explanation: The sudden release of high-pressure gas blasts magma, ash and rock into the air.

answers.content: Gas turns magma into solid rock instantly.
answers.explanation: Magma solidifies as it cools, not because of gas.

questions.question: Mount Vesuvius buried Pompeii in 79 AD. Describe ONE way this catastrophic event has provided modern scientists with information about ancient Roman daily life.

answers.content: The ash preserved loaves of bread in bakery ovens, so scientists learned about the types of food Romans ate.
answers.explanation: Any answer referencing preserved artefacts (buildings, bodies, tools, art) and the information they reveal earns full marks.

questions.question: Which planet hosts Olympus Mons, the tallest known volcano in the solar system?

answers.content: Earth
answers.explanation: Earth’s tallest volcano is Mauna Kea, much smaller.

answers.content: Mars
answers.explanation: Olympus Mons on Mars rises about 22 km high.

answers.content: Venus
answers.explanation: Venus has large volcanoes, but not Olympus Mons.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that shows how a volcanic eruption can both DESTROY and CREATE features in the landscape. Include at least THREE labels (e.g., lava flow, ash cloud, new island).

answers.content: Diagram must contain: (1) a destructive element (e.g., buried town), (2) a constructive element (e.g., new land or fertile soil), (3) three correct labels. Full marks for accuracy and completeness.
answers.explanation: Teacher uses rubric to award 0–3 marks based on inclusion of required elements and clarity of labels.

questions.question: Which term describes the natural process that breaks rocks into smaller pieces without moving them from their place?

answers.content: Weathering
answers.explanation: Weathering breaks down rocks in place.

answers.content: Erosion
answers.explanation: Erosion moves the broken pieces away.

answers.content: Deposition
answers.explanation: Deposition is the laying down of sediments.

answers.content: Sedimentation
answers.explanation: Sedimentation is another word for deposition.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three main agents of weathering studied in this lesson?

answers.content: Wind
answers.explanation: Wind is an agent of weathering.

answers.content: Moving water
answers.explanation: Water is an agent of weathering.

answers.content: Plants
answers.explanation: Plant roots can weather rocks.

answers.content: Moonlight
answers.explanation: Moonlight does not break down rocks.

questions.question: In one or two sentences, explain the difference between weathering and erosion.

answers.content: Weathering is the process that breaks down rocks into smaller pieces in the same place, while erosion transports those pieces to new locations by wind, water, ice or gravity.

questions.question: During the sugar-cube investigation, what caused the cubes to lose their sharp edges?

answers.content: A chemical reaction with air
answers.explanation: No chemical reaction occurred.

answers.content: Repeated collisions while shaking the jar
answers.explanation: The cubes weathered as they bumped together.

answers.content: Heat produced inside the jar
answers.explanation: Heat was not a factor.

answers.content: Exposure to sunlight
answers.explanation: Sunlight was not involved in the test.

questions.question: Write a strong topic sentence for a paragraph that explains how wind weathers rocks.

answers.content: Wind can weather rocks by blasting them with sand and other tiny particles carried through the air.

questions.question: Which causal connective best links cause and effect in an explanation of weathering?

answers.content: because
answers.explanation: “Because” shows why something happens.

answers.content: but
answers.explanation: “But” contrasts ideas.

answers.content: although
answers.explanation: “Although” shows concession.

answers.content: however
answers.explanation: “However” indicates contrast.

questions.question: Describe how plant roots can weather rock.

answers.content: As roots grow into small cracks, they widen the gaps and break the rock apart over time.

questions.question: Over thousands of years, river rocks become smooth mainly because of:

answers.content: Dissolving completely in water
answers.explanation: Most rocks do not fully dissolve.

answers.content: Abrasion from particles carried by flowing water
answers.explanation: Sand and gravel scrape the rocks smooth.

answers.content: Earth’s gravity alone
answers.explanation: Gravity helps movement but not the smoothing process.

answers.content: Heat from nearby volcanoes
answers.explanation: Volcanic heat is unrelated in this context.

questions.question: Draw a simple flow chart that shows the steps in which moving water changes a jagged rock into a smooth pebble. Include at least three labelled steps.

answers.content: Teacher-marked drawing
answers.explanation: Award 1 mark per correctly sequenced and labelled step up to 3 marks.

questions.question: Name two Australian landforms shaped by weathering that you researched in the lesson and state one similarity between them.

answers.content: Wave Rock and Karlu Karlu (Devils Marbles) are both shaped by long-term weathering of granite rock.

questions.question: What is erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: This describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand to another place.
answers.explanation: Erosion transports previously-weathered material from one location to another.

answers.content: The settling of sediment in a new location.
answers.explanation: This describes deposition.

answers.content: The heating of rocks by the Sun.
answers.explanation: Heating alone is not erosion.

questions.question: In the tray investigation, which variable was changed to test the effect on erosion?

answers.content: The amount of water poured into the trays.
answers.explanation: The same volume of water should be used for a fair test.

answers.content: The type of sand used in each tray.
answers.explanation: All trays use the same sand.

answers.content: The slope (steepness) of the tray.
answers.explanation: Only the slope of the tray was altered to test its effect on erosion.

answers.content: The length of the ‘river’ drawn in the sand.
answers.explanation: The river length stayed the same.

questions.question: Why does faster-moving water cause more erosion?

answers.content: It has greater force and can pick up more sediment.
answers.explanation: Greater speed means greater kinetic energy, increasing its ability to transport particles.

answers.content: It contains more dissolved minerals.
answers.explanation: Mineral content is not the main reason for increased erosion.

answers.content: It is usually warmer than slow water.
answers.explanation: Temperature difference is unrelated here.

answers.content: Fast water loses energy quickly.
answers.explanation: Fast water gains, not loses, kinetic energy.

questions.question: Name one natural force other than moving water that can cause erosion.

answers.content: wind
answers.explanation: Wind erosion moves sand and soil, especially in dry areas.

questions.question: Which tray in the investigation would you expect to show the LEAST erosion?

answers.content: Tray placed flat on the table.
answers.explanation: With no slope the water moves slowest, so it erodes the least.

answers.content: Tray propped with one book (gentle slope).
answers.explanation: A gentle slope causes some erosion but more than a flat tray.

answers.content: Tray propped with three books (steep slope).
answers.explanation: The steepest slope produces the most erosion.

answers.content: All trays show the same amount of erosion.
answers.explanation: Different slopes change water speed and erosion.

questions.question: Explain why keeping the amount of water the same in each tray makes the investigation a fair test.

answers.content: It ensures only slope affects erosion / controls other variables.
answers.explanation: If the water volume changed, differences in erosion could be due to water amount instead of slope.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that shows how water flowing down a steep slope can erode and carry sand from the top of the slope to the bottom.

answers.content: Student’s labelled diagram should show slope, water arrow, eroded path, deposited sand.
answers.explanation: Look for accurate representation of erosion and deposition.

questions.question: Which of the following human activities can increase water-caused shoreline erosion, according to the lesson extension?

answers.content: Planting mangroves along a riverbank.
answers.explanation: Plant roots can reduce erosion.

answers.content: Operating motorboats and jet skis at high speed near the shore.
answers.explanation: The waves they create add force that erodes the shoreline.

answers.content: Building boardwalks away from the waterline.
answers.explanation: This activity does not directly increase wave force.

answers.content: Reducing speed limits for boats close to shore.
answers.explanation: Lower speeds reduce, not increase, erosion.
